p.s: Sonnet 65 is a poem written by William Shakespeare and about the question, what real love can stop.
The poem has the typical Shakespearean structure with it'sits 14 lines and four stances, of which three have four verses.
The last two lines are the final couplet.
The iambic parameter is the metre, with it'sits typical heartbeat rhythm.
The three quartrainsquatrains have a cross rhyme at the end of each vese, while the final couplet has a pair-rhyme.
This turns our well through using enjambementsenjambments in the first two and in the fifth and sixth lines.
The first quartrainquatrain describes the power of love, which is indestructible, except from the death.
But this power is only in mind and does not take action in the real life.
The second quartrainquatrain comprises the problem, that the time to take actions is getting less, even if it is an inner fight.
In the last two lines of the third quartrainquatrain the lyrical I asked what the adresseeaddressee even holds back and what he needs to make his mind come true.
The answer in the final couplet is, that he writes about his love and hopes that it will come true.
